awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Transmission Electron Microscope Specimen Holder for Imaging Quantum Matter and Other Extreme Low-Temperature Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the potential development of methods to characterize quantum devices and other materials at ultra-low temperatures.  Many advanced materials for critical next-generation technologies are interesting to study but can only be tested at very low temperatures. These include quantum materials and devices used for quantum computing, magnets, superconductors, batteries, and more. The proposed technology may allow for structural characterization of these devices at or near their operating temperatures. More broadly, some material specimens such as polymers, battery electrolytes, and biological matter are highly sensitive to conditions found inside an electron microscope and are easily damaged or destroyed during imaging. Cooling these specimens may preserve their structure by slowing or arresting pathways to degradation and allow for sustained structural characterization using real-space imaging. The proposed technology may enable useful atomic resolution imaging for a variety of applications in a wide range of industries.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of an atomically stable specimen holder for use within transmission electron microscopes (TEM) that enables extreme low-temperature cryogenic imaging of materials at atomic resolution. Existing technological attempts have been unable to provide low-temperature imaging of materials due to excessive vibrations and instability introduced by traditional cooling methods. Advancement also has been challenged by limited physical space that makes the introduction of cryogens and other stimuli difficult. The proposed technology focuses on designs to potentially overcome space constraints imposed by electron microscopes and reduce vibration to enable stable imaging. This project will evaluate the commercial impact of atomic resolution low-temperature electron microscopy on the quantum device, semiconductor, and soft biological, and chemical material industries to enable next-generation computational and electronic technologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor

por.por_cntn:
Market discovery through this ICorps program established a viable pathway to bring to market a disruptive TEM holder design that enables customers to meaningfully image and measure their materials and devices at atomic resolution and at the required ultra-low temperatures. In particular, R&D scientists will be able to see the arrangement of atoms and electrons in their novel materials at low temperatures, which opens the door to improving quantum computing chips, understanding the molecular structure of polymers, and optimizing devices for non-classical computing.

The customers identified are scientists and R&D engineers seeking to understand failure mechanisms and defects in processes and materials that require extreme low temperatures, with the ultimate goal of optimizing the performance of new technologies. As novel materials permeate innovations in many industries, customers come from a wide range of technical fields, from semiconductor and quantum, to biological and chemical. TEM is a widely-deployed, gold standard tool in biological structure determination and semiconductor metrology. However, critically needed materials such as polymers, energy materials, and quantum devices have not benefited from atomic-scale TEM characterization due to a severe and long-standing lack of ultra-low-temperature capabilities. These R&D scientists and engineers require the SBIR technology herein to measure atomic-scale structure and chemistry of their materials at the requisite ultra-low temperatures.

A vibrant, growing ecosystem of TEM manufacturers and accessory companies including holder companies was discovered through this work. Some of these companies provide cryogenic holders utilizing the small dewar designs. Despite their broad deployment, these instruments suffer from insufficient hold times and are not cold enough to image many materials. Instrusty scientists and academics demand not yet realized ultra-low temperatures (sub-10 K) with high temperature stability (< 2 mK), and, importantly, very long hold times (over 8 hours).

The ultra-cold TEM holder technology established by this team reaches low temperatures with stability never before achieved and was found to meet the requirements of industry and academics developing next generation semiconductor and quantum applications. A TEM holder product ecosystem was derived from Regional and National NSF I-Corps interviews.

 


Last Modified: 07/12/2024
Modified by: Robert Hovden
